author: Victoria Ward
title: RideLondon: Everything you need to know about how to get around London
text:
Follow 
Motorists have been warned to avoid much of London this weekend as the capital grinds to a standstill as it hosts one of the country’s biggest cycling events. 
Around 100,000 amateur and professional cyclists will take part in the Prudential RideLondon festival on Saturday and Sunday, including Sir Bradley Wiggins, Mark Cavendish, Laura Trott and Dani King. 
It will involve road closures on one of the greatest scales London has ever seen, with “hundreds” of roads closed, including 13 Thames bridges, the Blackwall tunnel, Hyde Park Corner and the Hammersmith flyover. 
On Saturday, the disruption is largely confined to Central London, when up to 70,000 people are expected to take part in a traffic-free ten-mile loop of Westminster and the City. 
But on Sunday, the RideLondon-Surrey event will see it will spread as far east as the Blackwall Tunnel and throughout Richmond and Surrey as thousands of cyclists take on a 100-mile challenge through London and Surrey before finishing on The Mall. 
Road users have been advised to avoid the event routes wherever possible and to use Tubes and trains to get around. Many buses will be on diversion or will stop short of their destinations. 
Garrett Emmerson, chief operating officer of surface transport at TfL, said: “Prudential RideLondon is an established highlight of the Capital’s calendar. Londoners now expect and look forward to seeing the tens of thousands of cyclists, from first-timers to Tour de France winners, on their roads each summer – inspiring more and more people to make cycling their way of getting around London. 
“We’re asking everyone to use the information we’re giving and plan their travel on Prudential RideLondon weekend to ensure the maximum enjoyment of the events and all London has to offer.” Road closures 
(Alamy) 
On Saturday, the road closures will begin at 6am and most will have reopened by 6pm. 
Waterloo Bridge will be closed but all other London river crossings will remain open. 
On Sunday, road closures will be in place from 4aam throughout parts of east, central and south west London. 
In central London, they include Tower Hill, Cannon Street, Trafalgar Square, Pall Mall, Piccadilly, Millbank, Whitehall and The Mall. 
In east London, they include the A12, the A102, the Blackwall Tunnel and the A13. 
In west London, roads affected include Putney Bridge, Putney High Street, Chelsea Embankment, Talgarth Road, Chiswick Bridge and Brompton Road. 
The A4 eastbound between Hogarth Roundabout and Warwick Road at Earls Court remains open throughout the day 
In Surrey, there will be rolling closures in Walton-on-Thames, Weybridge, Byfleet, Ripley, Dorking, Box Hill village, Leatherhead, Oxshott, Esher and Thames Ditton, among others. 
The A3 will be open all day, although the junctions at Esher Common, Coombe Lane and Tibbet’s Corner will be closed. 
The M25 is open as normal. The A244 at Walton is closed between 7am and 11.30am. 
Several Thames bridges will be closed until the evening, including London Bridge, Tower Bridge and Waterloo Bridge. Blackfriars Bridge will remain open but is expected to be busier than normal. 
From around 10:30am, roads along the 100 mile Prudential RideLondon-Surrey route will be opened in phases once the event has passed and it is safe to do so. 
All roads are expected to be reopen by 8.30pm. Airport services 
Coach services to and from Victoria Coach station will be affected on Sunday. 
Heathrow Airport services will be diverted between Victoria and Heathrow 
Gatwick Airport National Express services from Victoria will start and terminate at Vauxhall. EasyBus from West Brompton will start and terminate at Imperial Wharf. River 
River Bus and River Tour services will be running a normal service with some piers close to the main spectator viewing points at Canary Wharf, Tower Hill and Westminster. 
The Woolwich Ferry will run an extended one-boat service from 6am until 7.30pm on Sunday. Tube and rail 
There is a good service on most Tube lines this weekend and people are strongly advised to use the trains wherever possible. 
However, there will be partial closures on the Circle, District, Hammersmith and City and Jubilee lines. 
There are no major works scheduled on the rail. What’s on and where to watch 
Saturday: 
The FreeCycle event kicks off at 9am and finishes at 4pm. It is a family-friendly mass bike ride through central London. 
The Grand Prix event comprises a series of elite races on a closed-road circuit in and around St James’s Park, kicking off at 5pm on Saturday. 
Sunday: 
On Sunday morning, the London-Surrey amateurs 100 race starts at the Olympic Park in east London at 6am, then heads out to Surrey and back again to cross the finish line on The Mall. 
The Surrey Classic involves 150 professional cyclists, including Sir Bradley and Cavendish, racing along a 124 mile route from Horse Guards Parade, taking in St James’s Park and then heading into Surrey before returning to the capital to finish on The Mall. It starts on Sunday at 1.30pm. 
Special spectator points are at the Queen Elizabeth Park, Canary Wharf, Tower of London, St Paul's, Trafalgar Square, Richmond Park, the Memorial Gardens in Kingston, Parliament Square, Whitehall, The Mall and Buckingham Palace. 
Around 30 elite handcyclists will also take to the roads on Sunday morning at 8.30am, starting in Kingston and finishing on The Mall at around 9.15am. 
Spectator points for this race will be at St James's Park, Green Park, Westminster, and Piccadilly Circus.
